thread.title: Hunter Valley farmer buying feed and water as dry conditions bite
thread.title_full: Hunter Valley farmer buying feed and water as dry conditions bite

author: Robert Virtue
title: Hunter Valley farmer buying feed and water as dry conditions bite
text:
Map: East Gresford 2311 
A farmer in the New South Wales Hunter Valley has been dealt a second blow, months after being affected by the dairy price wars of 2016 . 
It has been a long, hot summer , and in the Hunter region temperatures have regularly pushed over 40 degrees. 
There has been little rainfall, and for farmers, the extended dry period is beginning to hurt. 
"It's pretty well as bad as what we've seen for a long time," dairy farmer Ken Turnbull said. 
"You'd most probably have to go back to the drought in 1979, '80, '81 to equal these sort of conditions that we're in now." No good rain for months Photo: There has not been good rainfall around Gresford since July 2016. (1233 ABC Newcastle: Robert Virtue) 
Mr Turnbull's family has farmed land around Gresford since the mid-1940s, and he is now running low on water and feed for his dairy cattle herd. 
"Water at the moment, we're running on a creek. We've had to cut right back. We haven't irrigated any of the farm since November out of the creek," he said. 
"We have done a little bit of irrigating out of our irrigation dam, but that's gone down pretty well now. 
"We're virtually just trying to save the water that's in the creek now for stock and domestic [use]. 
"The gardens are gone. The beloved vegie patch has gone by the wayside. It's fairly critical. 
"It's hard to use that dreaded D word, but yeah I think this area would be in drought. 
"If it's not a drought, it's a damn-bad spell." 
The last good rainfall in the Gresford area was in July. 
Mr Turnbull said thunderstorms that had rolled in had, by-and-large, missed his pocket of the region. 
"It's pretty concerning. We've used all our conserved fodder that we save up for winter," he said. 
"[In] the next couple of weeks, we'll be buying semi-trailer loads of hay, and we've also had to buy in water to put through the machines at the dairy." Dry conditions a second hit for farmer 
For Mr Turnbull, the extended dry spell comes on top of being caught-up in last year's dairy price wars . 
Late last year he was receiving on average $0.40 per litre for his milk. 
That price has now risen, but it is still not enough. 
"That 52 cents is still two or three cents below our average price for the 12 months before. It's still going to be difficult," Mr Turnbull said. 
"Any extra money that you're making at the moment is going straight back into buying grain or buying hay." Community rallying in time of need 
For those living and working in the area, the dry spell is the talk of the town. 
"Everybody gets together and talks about it. It's just rural life," Mr Turnbull said. 
"Everybody sticks together and if somebody needs a hand, well they've only got to ask and people will be there to help. 
"Maybe you keep [the farm] going for the kids and the grandkids, and you find a way to work through things. 
"You've got to be able to communicate to other people, talk to other people. If you bottle it all up and didn't talk to other farmers or other friends, it'd be pretty hard." 
Mr Turnbull said 200–300 millimetres of soaking rain over a few weeks would turn the situation around. 
"I don't know if there's much that people can do. Do rain dances or something like that for us," he said. 
"It's just one of those things that happens in Australia, out in the country." Photo: The Allyn River at Gresford is drying up. (1233 ABC Newcastle: Robert Virtue) Is it a drought? 
Hunter Local Land Services district veterinarian Digby Raywood said officially declaring an area as being in drought was old terminology. 
"The old terminology of officially declaring an area drought — they are then eligible for some transport subsidies," he said. 
"So we're not actually officially declared drought because that declaration goes on a council-whole area. 
"But certainly that district up there [Gresford], in my interpretation is drought-affected, there's no doubt about it." 
Mr Raywood said Local Land Services ran information days to support affected farmers. 
"All we try and advise people is, get prepared for it. Doing nothing is not an option," he said. 
"A beef guy has got some more options, they're able to sell their stock off. 
"The dairy guys are locked in to producing milk, and so their options are very limited, and their cost of production goes through the roof. 
"They are in desperate times."
